lead_paragraph: When McDonald’s opened its first restaurant in China in the early 1990s, it did not turn to local suppliers for meat, which most likely would have been cheaper. Instead, it relied on its longtime partner the OSI Group, which had been linked to the fast-food titan ever since Ray Kroc, the McDonald’s founder, in the 1950s tapped the Chicago butcher Otto & Sons to provide consistent, reliable meats to his expanding empire.

lead_paragraph: MARKETS FALL BUT STRATEGISTS SHRUG | The stock market ended July with the sharpest decline in the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index since April, while the Dow Jones industrial index fell more than 300 points, eliminating all of its gains for the year, Jeff Sommer writes in DealBook. The reasons for the losses on Thursday were not entirely clear ‒ a few disappointing earnings reports, Argentina’s default and fears about global conflict may all have been factors. But whatever the causes of the decline, it wasn’t entirely unexpected, and the reaction of several strategists was fairly upbeat.

snippet: Genevieve Bell, an anthropologist who is also an Intel Fellow, looks at how tech changes the world, and vice versa. She is convinced we are at a rare period of social change, with the explosion of digital intelligence into every part of our lives.
lead_paragraph: Genevieve Bell grew up among Aboriginal people in Australia, taught anthropology at Stanford and for the past 16 years has worked for Intel. It all shows in her lively mind: Ask her the time and, along with the hour, you might hear about how native Australian languages fuse the words for past, present and land, along with the history of the mechanical clock and how that determined people’s feelings about robots.

abstract: A vote to effectively end a program for undocumented children is unlikely to hurt the G.O.P. in midterm elections because Hispanic voters are underrepresented in close races.
snippet: A vote to effectively end a program for undocumented children is unlikely to hurt the G.O.P. in midterm elections because Hispanic voters are underrepresented in close races.
lead_paragraph: Republican hopes for attracting more Hispanic voters suffered another setback on Friday when the House passed a bill to effectively end President Obama’s program to defer deportations of undocumented children. Yet the vote is unlikely to deal a severe blow to the party’s chances in November’s midterm elections. Hispanic voters may be flexing their growing political muscles in presidential elections, but they have far less sway over the composition of the House or the Senate, particularly in 2014.

headline.main: Why House Deportation Vote Won’t Hurt the G.O.P.

abstract: In the excitement of admiring our newly acquired furniture, we failed to ask an important question: What will this new space say about who we are?

lead_paragraph: In February, my company, RJMetrics, moved into a new office. It was bittersweet to outgrow our old space, partially because it had a pretty amazing legacy. Before us, a company called VoiceStar had built a business in the exact same suite and sold it to Marchex for millions. “Those guys drove away in Ferraris,” our old landlord liked to say.

headline.main: Balancing Lean Company Culture With the Perks of Success

lead_paragraph: WHAT’S BEHIND THE STAMPEDE OF MERGERS | “Something big is happening on Wall Street that is making investment bankers richer,” Peter Eavis and David Gelles write in DealBook. That something is a boom in mergers and acquisitions, which is expected to continue even after Rupert Murdoch’s bid for Time Warner and Sprint’s attempt to buy T-Mobile crumbled earlier this week. A sharp upturn in deal activity is often thought to herald a stronger economy and a buoyant stock market. The theory is that corporate chieftains see strength building in their business lines, which gives them the confidence to pursue ambitious acquisitions of other companies.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: What’s Behind the Surge in Mergers

lead_paragraph: During photography of the 2015 BMW 435i convertible, I shot beautiful video of flowers, clouds, horses and scenic vistas along rural roads. Almost none of it is used in the piece. It’s not only about getting a deeper tan (something doctors will frown upon anyway).

lead_paragraph: RATNAGIRI DISTRICT, India — When the cashew harvest starts here, the orchards clinging to the lush, wrinkled hills are blanketed by a brilliant yellow, orange and red carpet, created after farmers pluck the nut and toss its stem to the ground. There, the cashew apples, as the stems are known, quickly rot, except for a few used to brew a local spirit called feni that is popular in neighboring Goa.

headline.print_headline: Apple of Pepsi’s Eye

Once I had that filled in, however, things sort of crawled to a snail’s pace — as opposed to a NAUTILUS’s — and it took me much longer to finish the puzzle than I had anticipated, considering that it only had 64 entries.

lead_paragraph: Rage is rising over American corporations that chop their tax bills by acquiring entities in lower-tax countries. Medtronic, AbbVie and Mylan have all announced such plans — known as inversions — in recent months. And Walgreen was poised to relocate to Switzerland after it completes its purchase of Alliance Boots, but did an about-face last week in the face of widespread denunciation.

abstract: Why is the giant A380 jet wowing passengers, but not many airlines? Its maker may have made the wrong bet on air travel’s future.

lead_paragraph: To get a sense of the Airbus A380’s size and ambition, walk up the grand staircase of an Emirates version of the aircraft, past the showers and the first-class suites and then through endless rows in business class to the bar at the back of the upper deck. This sleek semicircle, alluringly underlit and fully stocked with pricey spirits like Grey Goose vodka, is undoubtedly one of the defining features of this aircraft, which can hold more than 500 passengers. The plane dwarfs every commercial jet in the skies.

headline.main: Oversize Expectations for the Airbus A380
headline.print_headline: Oversize Expectations

headline.main: Variety: An Unpredictable Acrostic

abstract: A Sunday grid by Elizabeth C. Gorski can be considered a puzzler’s best friend.
snippet: A Sunday grid by Elizabeth C. Gorski can be considered a puzzler’s best friend.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — All together now: “Awwwww!” You cannot be sad doing this puzzle by Elizabeth C. Gorski, the mistress of visual puzzle art. Sorry, it’s not allowed. Even if you’re not a dog lover, you have to admit that this puzzle is pretty awesome. We’ve got an adorable pup drawn in the grid, and Ms. Gorski has managed to do that without even going over the 140 entry limit. That’s masterful in itself.

headline.main: No. 1 Friends

lead_paragraph: SMOKING had long been a hallmark of teenage rebellion when “Truth,” a campaign from Legacy, introduced its first antismoking commercial in 2000. In the commercial, young people gather at the New York headquarters of the Philip Morris tobacco company and dump 1,200 body bags, representing the number of daily deaths attributed to smoking. The spot sought to shift a perception of cigarettes as a symbol of rebellion to one of the tobacco industry as the real enemy to rebel against.

abstract: In the third installment of the Apology Metrics series, Dov Seidman invites readers to participate in a survey on the apology of Kevin Rudd to Australia’s indigenous community.
snippet: In the third installment of the Apology Metrics series, Dov Seidman invites readers to participate in a survey on the apology of Kevin Rudd to Australia’s indigenous community.
lead_paragraph: This is the third apology in our Apology Metrics series in which we present apologies for readers to assess. Our goal is not to evaluate apologies as theatrical performances but to evaluate the apologizer’s behavior over time to see whether there has been genuine change. This time, we will look at the apology of Kevin Rudd, the former prime minister of Australia, to Australia’s indigenous community in 2008. With the benefit of six years of hindsight, we are in a much better position to judge the apology’s authenticity.

headline.main: Measuring the Apology of Kevin Rudd, Former Prime Minister of Australia

abstract: Kinder Morgan’s reorganization puts master limited partnerships in question. | An arbitration panel has eased the blame on Ernst & Young for audits of Lehman Brothers. | New York prosecutors have accused payday lenders with usury. | Chiquita Brands has received a counter to its inversion plan.

lead_paragraph: When Kinder Morgan, a $100 billion empire that transports much of America’s oil and natural gas, announced on Sunday that it was abandoning the master limited partnership it helped popularize, questions emerged about what would happen to the many other such structures, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. Largely because of Kinder Morgan’s success, the partnerships have become increasingly popular for energy companies. The structure allows them to pass all profits along to their investors as dividends and pay no corporate taxes, though the investors are subject to taxes on the distributions.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Uncertainty Over Master Limited Partnerships

abstract: The Aloft hotel in Cupertino, Calif., will begin testing a robot that can shuttle items from the hotel lobby desk to guest rooms.

lead_paragraph: On Aug. 20, the Aloft hotel in Cupertino, Calif., across the street from Apple’s corporate campus, will begin testing “Botlr,” a robotic bellhop that can shuttle items from the hotel lobby desk to guest rooms. Whether a gimmick or a sign of things to come, Botlr is the latest among a new generation of robots — like Google’s self-driving car, Aetheon’s Tug hospital supply robot and Caddytrek’s electric golf caddy — that are starting to walk or roll around the everyday world, John Markoff reports.

headline.main: Daily Report: Silicon Valley Hotel Puts Robotic Bellhop to the Test

lead_paragraph: Will Power held off the fast-closing Juan Pablo Montoya by 2.794 seconds at the finish of the IndyCar race in Milwaukee on Sunday and now is in better position of winning his first series championship. Before the race, Power estimated that he would have to win two of the remaining three races this season to clinch the title. The races remaining include one in Sonoma, Calif., on Sunday and another on Aug. 30 in Fontana, Calif. Power has a 39-point lead over Helio Castroneves in the standings.

lead_paragraph: For years, chief executives have complained bitterly about the United States corporate tax code, arguing that it is too complicated and that rates are too high. The issue has reached a near boiling point this summer as many large American companies have sought to buy smaller foreign rivals so they can renounce their United States corporate citizenship and reincorporate overseas to lower their tax bills. Others are considering the move, known as an inversion.

lead_paragraph: When Dollar General offered on Monday to buy Family Dollar Stores for $8.9 billion, it was hoping not only to break up Family Dollar’s merger with Dollar Tree but also to strengthen its share of the low-end retail market, Michael J. de la Merced and Nelson D. Schwartz write in DealBook. “Prices at Family Dollar are kept low and its breadth of products is limited to items it can sell cheaply,” they write. “But the retailer’s success has become a symbol of the rush to cater to the working poor.”

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Dollar Store Deal Frenzy

abstract: Something is in the air lately, making many entrepreneurs forget the demise of services like Webvan and Kozmo during the last dot-com boom.
snippet: Something is in the air lately, making many entrepreneurs forget the demise of services like Webvan and Kozmo during the last dot-com boom.
lead_paragraph: In the tech crash of the early 2000s, on-demand delivery services like Kozmo and Webvan weren’t just among the most colossal failures. They also became a sort of grim joke, symbolizing the excess that portended the bust. Afterward, conventional wisdom hardened: Web-enabled delivery was not a good business. Warehouses were too costly to build. There was too little opportunity to recoup expenditures in delivery fees. And people will pay only so much for toilet paper to be delivered before they decide to fetch it themselves.

lead_paragraph: In a settlement announced on Tuesday by New York State’s financial regulator, the British bank Standard Chartered will pay a $300 million fine and suspend its dollar-clearing activities because of its failure to weed out transactions prone to money-laundering, Ben Protess and Chad Bray write in DealBook. The deal comes two years after the bank paid a combined $667 million to state and federal authorities over similar accusations. Those settlements resolved accusations that Standard Chartered, in part through its New York branch, processed transactions for Iran and other countries blacklisted by the United States.

abstract: The company’s chief executive found that his 10 sales representatives were falling far short of their sales goals.
snippet: The company’s chief executive found that his 10 sales representatives were falling far short of their sales goals.
lead_paragraph: We just published a case study about a frustrated founder of Yesware, a four-year-old company that makes software that helps sales teams by eliminating the need for sales representatives to spend time on data entry. To his dismay, Matthew Bellows, founder and chief executive of Yesware, saw his 10-person sales team fall far short of the sales goals he’d set. And that was with 100,000 known leads — current users of the software’s free version — seemingly primed to be converted into paying customers.

headline.main: Does Yesware Need to Hire a Vice President of Sales?

abstract: A $16.65 billion mortgage settlement with Bank of America is set to be announced. |Scrutiny is shifting to subprime auto loans. | Dollar General questions the motives of Family Dollar’s chief executive. | Argentina has introduced a bill to sidestep a U.S. court ruling.

lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is set to announce a $16.65 billion settlement with Bank of America over accusations that it duped investors into buying troubled mortgage securities, DealBook’s Ben Protess, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery write, according to people briefed on the matter. The accord would be the biggest government settlement by a company in American history. Prosecutors are also preparing a separate civil case against Angelo Mozilo, the man who came to embody the risk-taking for which Bank of America is now paying dearly, a rare move against a senior executive at the center of the financial crisis.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Bank of America Nears Huge Settlement

lead_paragraph: Burger King said on Sunday that it was in talks to buy Tim Hortons, the Canadian doughnut-and-coffee chain, in a potential deal that would create one of the world’s biggest fast-food chains, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. Should the deal be completed, it would mean Burger King’s corporate headquarters would move to Canada, raising the prospect of yet another United States company switching its national citizenship to lower its tax bill. The two companies are expected to argue that a merger would bring a host of strategic benefits, but it would nevertheless count as a so-called corporate inversion.

lead_paragraph: Think video games are just things people play? Think again. On Monday, Amazon announced that it had reached a $1.1 billion deal to buy Twitch, the most popular website for watching people play video games, Nick Wingfield writes in The New York Times. “The deal for Twitch is the latest sign of how forms of behavior once seemingly on the fringe can, in the hands of tech entrepreneurs, turn into huge online communities in no time,” he writes. Twitch, which specializes in live videos of people playing games, has 55 million unique viewers a month globally.

lead_paragraph: BUSINESSES WINNING THE TAX GAME | Across corporate America, companies large and small are finding new ways to avoid paying taxes, making it harder than ever for the federal government to replenish its already depleted coffers, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. As a result, business income tax revenue remains stagnant at about 2 percent of gross domestic product even as corporate profits hit records. Business taxes now make up less than 10 percent of federal revenue, down sharply from the years after World War II, when about 30 percent of federal revenue came from corporate taxes.

lead_paragraph: For 10 weeks, a group of Dinner Lab chefs cooked at events around the country, vying for high scores from diners and the opportunity to open their own restaurants. Here is a quick look at the three finalists and the types of restaurants they have in mind.

headline.main: The Culinary Contenders
headline.print_headline: The Culinary Contenders

abstract: Mr. Finney made advancing online privacy his life’s work, and he took part in the first Bitcoin transaction, when Satoshi Nakamoto sent him 10 Bitcoins.
snippet: Mr. Finney made advancing online privacy his life’s work, and he took part in the first Bitcoin transaction, when Satoshi Nakamoto sent him 10 Bitcoins.
lead_paragraph: Hal Finney, a cryptographer and one of the earliest users and developers of the virtual currency Bitcoin, died on Thursday in Phoenix. He was 58.

headline.main: Hal Finney, Cryptographer and Bitcoin Pioneer, Dies at 58
headline.print_headline: Hal Finney, Coder and Futurist, Dies at 58

abstract: Mr. White was a co-founder of the research firm Yankelovich, Skelly & White, who went on to help start many nonprofits, including Reading Is Fundamental.
snippet: Mr. White was a co-founder of the research firm Yankelovich, Skelly & White, who went on to help start many nonprofits, including Reading Is Fundamental.
lead_paragraph: Arthur H. White, a co-founder of Yankelovich, Skelly & White, an innovative opinion research firm that shed light on American cultural and political changes, who later became a prominent leader in the nonprofit world, died on Aug. 25 in Stamford, Conn. He was 90.

headline.main: Arthur H. White Dies at 90; Gauged Public Opinion and Encouraged Reading
headline.print_headline: Arthur H. White, 90, Dies; Gauged Public Opinion

abstract: Charles Shrem, a leading backer of Bitcoin, is to plead to one federal count of aiding and abetting an unlicensed money transmitting business.
snippet: Charles Shrem, a leading backer of Bitcoin, is to plead to one federal count of aiding and abetting an unlicensed money transmitting business.
lead_paragraph: A prominent supporter of Bitcoin, Charles Shrem, says he will plead guilty on Thursday to resolve federal charges that he helped smooth the way for drug transactions on the online marketplace Silk Road. He is to plead in New York to one count of aiding and abetting the operation of an unlicensed money transmitting business.

headline.main: Top Bitcoin Proponent to Plead Guilty to Federal Charge
headline.print_headline: Top Bitcoin Proponent to Plead Guilty to Federal Charge

headline.main: Heard at the Movies

abstract: The annual event draws more than 50,000 people to the Nevada desert — many of them from the tech industry in San Francisco. And while they’re away, the city’s hard-to-get-into restaurants and bars aren’t so hard to get into.
snippet: The annual event draws more than 50,000 people to the Nevada desert — many of them from the tech industry in San Francisco. And while they’re away, the city’s hard-to-get-into restaurants and bars aren’t so hard to get into.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As the annual Burning Man festival wrapped up over the holiday weekend, thousands of weary festivalgoers were somewhere in Nevada packing up yurts, washing off body paint and dreading their eventual re-entry to the real world. Here, particularly in the city’s rapidly gentrifying Mission District, their neighbors were dreading something else: the moment the “Burners” come home.

headline.main: San Francisco Exhales During ‘Burning Man Exodus’
headline.print_headline: Relief for San Franciscans as Some Frolic in Nevada
